results.title: Learning to understand children part 2 : a remedial program
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Teacher Education”.
This film is a continuation of the case study of Ada Adams: her teacher develops a plan for remedial action. This is a good film showing some of the specific remedial techniques which can be used with many types of maladjustments; it does a good job in showing how a child’s interest in art can be used to improve her self confidence and interest in school.

results.title: Problem method, using the information
results.creator_credit: George L. George, Theodore Karp and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Teacher Education”.
After gathering information to solve the pressure-group problem, the students in a social studies class suggest possible solutions to the problem and with the help of their teacher, develop a set of criteria against which the hypothesis can be tested. Follows the thinking process involved in testing teach hypothesis and in arriving at a solution to the problem. Emphasizes the importance of the use of the problem method in preparing student for democratic living.
results.creator_credit_for_label: George L. George, Theodore Karp and McGraw-Hill Films

results.title: Problem method, defining the problem
results.creator_credit: George L. George and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Teacher Education”.
After becoming aware of pressure groups and their influence on legislation, the students in a social studies class, with the help of their teacher, define and analyse the problem and endeavour to find information upon which to base a satisfactory solution. Shows the procedures employed by the students in fathering and sharing information.

results.title: Urban Aboriginal artists (A)
results.creator_credit: Christoph Willing, David Roberts, Peter Lipscombe and University of Sydney Television Service
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Talking about Aboriginal art”.
While the three artists in this video cannot speak for all city-based Aboriginal artists, they raise issues central to the art-making of urban Aboriginals and the problems and controversies surrounding such art. They discuss issues of identity, their views on differences between black and white Australians and social issues of concern to their communities. Michael Riley has a growing reputation as a photographer and film maker, portraying the myths and misconceptions of Aboriginality. Trevor Nickolls has developed a strong iconography in his paintings which attempt to reconcile his black and white heritage. Jeffrey Samuels portrays his cultural heritage through his paintings using contemporary techniques, reflecting on stereotypes, tradition and nature.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christoph Willing, David Roberts, Peter Lipscombe and University of Sydney Television Service

results.title: Aboriginal art: conserving, exhibiting, interpreting
results.creator_credit: Christoph Willing, David Roberts, Peter Lipscombe and University of Sydney Television Service
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Talking about Aboriginal art”.
In recent decades Aboriginal art has increasingly been destined for art museums and major private collections. It has not been totally subsumed into the Western art dealer and museum system, but has made curators and art historians ask some profound questions about their practices and policies of collecting and exhibiting art. One concern is the involvement of non- Aboriginal curators and art advisers, with many believing they occupy positions which would be more appropriately held by Aboriginal people. Curators Djon Mundine, Wally Caruana and Peter Sutton discuss gallery collecting policies, major exhibitions and key issues in the criticism of contemporary Aboriginal art.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christoph Willing, David Roberts, Peter Lipscombe and University of Sydney Television Service

results.title: Aboriginal women artists (A)
results.creator_credit: Christoph Willing, David Roberts, Peter Lipscombe and University of Sydney Television Service
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Talking about Aboriginal art”.
The images by the four Aboriginal women artists in this video program challenge old steroetypes that have seen the artistic activities of Aboriginal women as limited to crafts and body decoration. They use media techniques with which Western artists are familiar but the imagery is distinctively their own revealing the artist’s Aboriginality, whether she lives in a tradition-oriented community or an urban environment. Banduk Marika produces linocuts and fabric designs often involving stories from her clan group. Fiona Foley works in a variety of contemporary media to produce work about her history and against popular stereotypes of Aboriginal people. Bronwyn Bancroft is known for her fabrics, fashion designs and paintings utilizing images of her family and Koori heritage. Euphemia Bostock has helped bring international attention to Koorie fashion design and art through her teaching and practice.

results.title: Tradition and change: art from the desert (A)
results.creator_credit: Christoph Willing, David Roberts, Peter Lipscombe and University of Sydney Television Service
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Talking about Aboriginal art”.
In the past two decades Aboriginal art has flourished and diversified to a phenomenal extent. A many-faceted art movement has developed, with artists from communities all around Australia contributing fresh visions. Critics and the general public are excited by its inventiveness and aesthetic appeal. Its difference from traditional Aboriginal art has caused much controversy. Hetti Perkins introduces contemporary Aboriginal art, its themes and the issues. Geoff Bardon gives a personal account of the beginnings of the Papunya painting movement when he encouraged senior men to paint their Dreaming Stories in acrylics. Michael Nelson Jakamarra, recognized internationally as one of the outstanding artists from the Papuya central desert community, talks about his country and his art.
results.title_for_label: Tradition and change: art from the desert (A)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christoph Willing, David Roberts, Peter Lipscombe and University of Sydney Television Service
